conversations.content: What was the gain in net worth for Berkshire Hathaway Inc. during 1989?
Our gain in net worth during 1989 was $1.515 billion, which translates to a 44.4% increase. I'm pleased with that performance, and it's a testament to our team's hard work.
How has the per-share book value of Berkshire Hathaway Inc. changed since you took over 25 years ago?

Since I took the reins, our per-share book value has grown from $19.46 to $4,296.01. That's a compounded annual growth rate of 23.8%. It's a remarkable journey, and I'm proud of what we've accomplished.
What is the main obstacle you face in achieving high growth rates for Berkshire's net worth, and how does this relate to the example of bacteria growth described by Carl Sagan?

The main obstacle we face is that high growth rates must eventually self-destruct in a finite world. Carl Sagan's example of bacteria growth illustrates this point nicely. Just as the bacteria's exponential growth is eventually halted by obstacles like running out of food or poisoning each other, our own growth at Berkshire will be limited by our increasingly large base of net worth. It's simple math: the bigger you are, the harder it is to keep growing at a rapid pace.
How did taxes impact Berkshire's gain in 1989, and what was the significance of this gain in relation to your company's overall performance?

Taxes took a significant bite out of our 1989 gain - we had to pay about $712 million in income taxes. Despite this, we still managed to achieve a gain of $1.5 billion, which is a testament to our overall performance. It's worth noting, however, that our growth rate is likely to slow down from here, given our large and growing base of net worth. We're not expecting to double our net worth every 15 minutes, unfortunately!
How does the deferred tax liability on your balance sheet compare to a traditional liability payable to a trade creditor?

Well, they're not equal, despite having the same effect on our audited net worth. The deferred tax liability is more like an interest-free loan from the U.S. Treasury that comes due only when we choose to sell our securities. It's a unique situation, and I think it's helpful to think of it that way.
Can you provide an example of how this deferred tax liability has affected your investment decisions or outcomes in the past?

Yes, in 1989, we sold some smaller holdings and incurred about $76 million in taxes on $224 million of gains. It's a good illustration of how the tax law works and why our long-term investing approach, which I like to call 'Rip Van Winkle' style, has a mathematical edge over more frequent buying and selling.
How does the configuration of hundreds of participants selling a commodity-like product at independently-established prices affect industry profitability?

Well, it's quite simple really. This setup is bound to cause subnormal profitability most of the time. It's like trying to make a profit in a crowded marketplace where everyone's selling the same thing - it's tough unless there's a shortage of what you're selling, which in our case is usable capacity.
What determines the amount of industry capacity in the insurance world, and how effective are the constraints in place?

In the insurance world, capacity is typically described in financial terms, but to be honest, those constraints haven't proven very effective. It mostly comes down to the mental state of insurance managers - they can choose to write a lot of business with relatively little capital if they want to. Regulators, brokers, and customers are often slow to step in and discipline companies that overextend themselves.
What is the expected drop in Berkshire's premium volume in 1990 compared to its high in 1986?
Our premium volume may drop to $150 million or so in 1990, which is a significant decrease from our high of $1 billion in 1986. That's a pretty steep fall, but as I said, it won't disturb us.
How do CAT covers work in terms of loss payment and reinstatement?

CAT covers are reinsurance contracts that primary insurance companies buy to protect themselves against large catastrophes. Here's how they work: the primary insurer retains the loss up to a certain amount, say $10 million, and then the reinsurer pays 95% of the excess up to its limit. The primary insurer keeps 5% of each layer, so they have a stake in each loss settlement. And if their coverage is exhausted, they can buy a second cover for the rest of the year by paying another premium. It's a way for us to provide protection while also making sure the primary insurer has some skin in the game.
What is your current situation with float compared to premium volume, and how do you expect it to affect your insurance results?

We currently hold an exceptional amount of float compared to premium volume. I expect this to produce quite favorable insurance results for us during the next few years, similar to what we saw in 1989. Our underwriting losses should be manageable, and the investment income from policyholder funds should be substantial.
How do you approach selecting marketable securities for your insurance companies?

When it comes to choosing marketable securities, we consider five major categories and look for the highest after-tax returns. We don't have a bias towards any particular category; we just focus on finding investments that we understand and that will maximize our eventual net worth, rather than trying to boost short-term earnings.
What triggered your decision to finally invest in Coca-Cola in 1988?

It was when my brain finally established contact with my eyes, and I saw the incredible turnaround Roberto Goizueta and Don Keough had achieved since taking over in 1981. Their perfect blend of marketing and financial skills had given the company new momentum, especially with sales exploding overseas.
Why do you think Roberto Goizueta was so successful in leading Coca-Cola?

Roberto had a truly rare blend of marketing and financial skills, which allowed him to maximize both the growth of the product and the rewards that this growth brings to shareholders. Unlike many CEOs who might favor one discipline over the other, Roberto's approach was perfectly balanced, making him a dream for shareholders like me.
What are the key features of the Champion International Corp. preferred stock you purchased?

The Champion International Corp. preferred stock we bought has a few attractive features: it's got a mandatory redemption in ten years, pays a 9 1/4% dividend, and can be converted into common stock at $38 per share. Plus, it's structured in a way that we can't sell or convert it for a while, which means we won't be tempted to try to time the market or react to short-term price swings.
Why do you say you're 'agnostics, not atheists' when it comes to the future of certain industries like investment banking or airlines?

Well, when I say we're 'agnostics, not atheists,' I mean that we don't have strong feelings one way or the other about the long-term prospects of those industries. We're not predicting doom and gloom, but we also don't have enough insight to make a confident bet on their future. It's not that we think they're bad businesses, it's just that we don't understand them well enough to invest in them with the same level of conviction that we do in businesses like Gillette, which we think we understand pretty well.
What do you expect to get from your investment in preferred stocks, and what would be a disappointing outcome?

I expect to get my money back plus dividends from these preferred stocks. However, if that's all we get, it'll be a disappointing outcome because we'll have missed out on other significant opportunities due to the lack of flexibility in these investments. It's like putting money in a savings account - it's safe, but you're not going to get rich off the interest alone.
How do you plan to work with the CEOs of the companies you've invested in through preferred stocks?

Charlie and I plan to be supportive, analytical, and objective in our dealings with these CEOs. We recognize they're experienced and in command of their businesses, but we're also happy to provide a sounding board for their ideas, unencumbered by industry ties or past decisions. It's a collaborative approach, really.
How does the tax treatment of Berkshire's bonds benefit the company?

The tax treatment of our bonds is a significant benefit to us. Since we're entitled to deduct the 5.5% interest accrual each year, even though we make no payments to the bondholders, it results in reduced taxes and positive cash flow for Berkshire.
What's the difference between Berkshire's bonds and the typical zero-coupon bonds that you and Charlie have criticized?

Our bonds are quite different from the typical zero-coupon bonds that have been issued in recent years. For one, the taxable holders of our bonds have to pay tax each year on the 5.5% interest, even though they receive no cash. This symmetry in the tax law is key. We've been critical of other zero-coupon bonds because they've often been used deceptively, but our bonds, and those of a few other companies like Loews and Motorola, don't resemble those problematic bonds.
What is the main advantage of zero-coupon bonds to the issuers, according to you?
The main advantage of zero-coupon bonds to the issuers is that it's impossible to default on a promise to pay nothing. It's a clever way for shaky credits to avoid default, at least for a while.
How did the lending practices change over time during the leveraged buy-out craze, in your observation?

Well, when the leveraged buy-out craze first started, lenders were reasonably cautious, requiring borrowers to have enough free cash flow to cover both interest and debt reduction. But as time went on and deal-makers got more aggressive, lenders started accepting deals where all the free cash flow went towards paying interest, with no plan to pay down the principal. It was like a Scarlett O'Hara approach - 'I'll think about it tomorrow' - and it wasn't a very sound way of doing business, if you ask me.
What happens to a business if it routinely skips capital outlays and doesn't make them up?

Well, just like a human body weakens and eventually dies if it doesn't get the nourishment it needs, a business will weaken and eventually die if it doesn't invest in itself through capital outlays. It's not a matter of if, but when, the business will start to feel the effects of neglecting its own needs.
How did promoters and investment bankers justify ignoring depreciation expense and a portion of interest expense when assessing the financial feasibility of a transaction?

They came up with a clever trick - or so they thought. They started measuring EBDIT against cash interest only, which allowed them to ignore depreciation expense and the interest accruing on zero-coupon or PIK bonds. It's a bit like stepping through the Looking Glass, where up is down and down is up. Unfortunately, many professional investment managers bought into this nonsense, but usually only with their clients' money, not their own.
What do you suggest doing when investment bankers show you income and balance sheet projections for a company they barely knew a few months prior?

I suggest you join in the fun and ask the investment banker for their own firm's one-year budgets from the last few years, and then compare those with what actually happened. It's a great way to gauge the reliability of their projections.
Can you explain how zero-coupon bonds can create the illusion of 'earnings' for bondholders?

Well, with zeros, it's possible for one party to experience 'income' without the other feeling the pinch of expenditure. For instance, a company that can only earn $100 million annually can still magically create 'earnings' of $150 million for bondholders. It's a bit of financial wizardry that doesn't quite add up, if you ask me.
What was your first mistake in your investment career, as mentioned in the text?
My first mistake was buying control of Berkshire, despite knowing its textile manufacturing business was unpromising, because the price looked cheap at the time.
Can you explain what you mean by the 'cigar butt' approach to investing?

The 'cigar butt' approach is when you buy a stock at a very low price, hoping to make a profit even if the business itself isn't doing well. It's like finding a cigar butt on the street with one puff left - it's not much, but since it's free, that one puff is all profit. However, I've come to realize that this approach is foolish unless you're a liquidator, because the original 'bargain' price often isn't as good a deal as you think.
What did you learn from your experience with Hochschild Kohn and how do you approach buying companies or stocks now?

Well, I learned the hard way that it's far better to buy a wonderful company at a fair price than a fair company at a wonderful price. Now, when buying companies or common stocks, Charlie and I look for first-class businesses accompanied by first-class managements. It's a simple yet important lesson: good businesses with good management are more likely to succeed than average businesses, even with good management.
You mention that you and Charlie haven't learned how to solve difficult business problems after 25 years. Can you elaborate on what you mean by that?

What I mean is that we've found that some businesses are just inherently tough to fix, no matter how hard you try or how smart your management team is. As I said, 'Good jockeys will do well on good horses, but not on broken-down nags.' We've learned to focus on buying businesses with good economic characteristics, rather than trying to turn around struggling ones. It's just easier to succeed when you're starting with a strong foundation.
What approach do you and Charlie take when it comes to business problems, and why has it been successful for you?

We've found that it's best to stick with the easy and obvious, rather than trying to tackle tough problems. We look for one-foot hurdles that we can step over, rather than trying to clear seven-footers. This approach has been successful for us because it allows us to focus on what we're good at, rather than trying to be heroes and solve every difficult problem that comes our way.
You mention the 'institutional imperative' as a surprising discovery in business. Can you explain what you mean by this term?

The institutional imperative refers to the way that organizations can exert a kind of pressure on their managers to make decisions that aren't necessarily rational. I learned that even decent, intelligent, and experienced managers can make irrational decisions when the institutional imperative comes into play. It's a force that can cause people to act in ways that aren't in the best interest of the business, and it's something that I didn't understand when I first started out in business.
What have you learned about the institutional imperative and its impact on businesses?

I've learned that the institutional imperative can lead businesses down misguided paths, not because of venality or stupidity, but due to inherent institutional dynamics. It's like Newton's First Law of Motion - institutions resist change and tend to keep doing what they're doing, even if it's not the best course. I've also seen how this imperative can cause companies to mindlessly imitate their peers and pursue projects just because they have the funds available.
How do you approach investing in and partnering with other companies, given your understanding of the institutional imperative?

I try to invest in companies that are aware of the institutional imperative and its potential pitfalls. Charlie and I look for businesses with decent economic characteristics and leaders who are alert to these issues. Additionally, I've learned to only go into business with people I like, trust, and admire. It's not a guarantee of success, but it's a crucial starting point. After all, you can't make a silk purse out of a sow's ear, but with the right people and a good business, you can accomplish wonders.
